{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2958450,"name":"Jack Mechem","username":"JackMechem","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jackmechem/{size}/154110_2.png","created_at":"2021-06-15T18:56:31.788Z","cooked":"

Hello. I am using c++. I am using this documentation: Using Motor Controllers in Code ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

for some reason, it works fine but not in the correct direction. When I make the value positive instead of negative, the motor will step, it is not continuous.

here is what I am trying to do:

    frc::Spark spark{2}; // 0 is the RIO PWM port this is connected to

  spark.Set(0.75); // the % output of the motor, between -1 and 1   THIS IS THE VALUE I CHANGED


  frc::VictorSP victor{2}; // 0 is the RIO PWM port this is connected to

  victor.Set(.6); // the % output of the motor, between -1 and 1    I DONT KNOW WHAT THIS MEANS
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2021-06-15T18:56:57.949Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":143,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":742.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":394621,"topic_slug":"using-a-motor-in-the-inverse-direction","display_username":"Jack Mechem","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/actuators/using-motor-controllers.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Using Motor Controllers in Code ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48277,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-a-motor-in-the-inverse-direction/394621/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2958462,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2021-06-15T19:25:08.092Z","cooked":"

First of all, this is the old version of the docs. Try this instead:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

FIRST Robotics Competition Control System

Welcome to the FIRST ¬Æ Robotics Competition Control System Documentation! An overview of the changes from 2020 to 2021 is available on the New for 2021 document. Zero to Robot, Introduction, Step 1...

Next, if your motor is ‚Äújittering‚Äù in one direction or the other, the most likely cause is that you have two different controller.Set() calls in each loop, one of which is always negative if it works negative but not positive.

And finally, it‚Äôs much easier to troubleshoot your problem if we can see all of your code. The usual way to do this is to post it to github or similar and provide a link.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2021-06-15T19:25:55.490Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":59.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":394621,"topic_slug":"using-a-motor-in-the-inverse-direction","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FIRST Robotics Competition Control System ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/using-a-motor-in-the-inverse-direction/394621/2","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2958496,"name":"Kim","username":"krf","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/krf/{size}/158158_2.png","created_at":"2021-06-15T19:33:58.817Z","cooked":"

So, when we say the percent output is between -1 and 1, we mean that -1 is 100% the voltage of the battery input, hooked up completely backwards, which for brushed DC Motors (that you use with a Spark) forces them backwards. 0 would be ‚Äúno output‚Äù or neutral, and 1 would be ‚Äúfull speed forward‚Äù.

Setting .75 means 75% battery voltage applied ‚Äúpositively‚Äù, and .6 is 60% of battery voltage applied positively. Doing both of these in the same robot periodic function will result in a slight jitter.

Your example snippet has two motor controller objects on the same physical port, which I can‚Äôt recall offhandedly if it‚Äôll work at all but it‚Äôs certainly not a good idea. I suspect the jittering you report is related to that, or there‚Äôs a motor controller wiring issue.

And the documentation you‚Äôre looking at is correct.

I‚Äôm not seeing anything terribly wrong at first glace. Have you tried running your code in simulation? This will let you double-check what values you‚Äôre driving in your code to the PWM outputs. If simulation looks good it could be a cal issue on the motor controllers.
